nodes.bodyText: This is problematic. We are looking at the thread on the server. I think we need to send a message for this one, but definitely needs more thought. It is the default behavior though.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -4220,7 +4221,7 @@ TR_J9VMBase::initializeLocalObjectFlags(TR::Compilation * comp, TR::Node * alloc
    int32_t initValue = TR::Compiler->cls.romClassOf(ramClass)->instanceShape;
 #endif
 
-   if (!TR::Options::getCmdLineOptions()->realTimeGC())
+   if (!comp->getOptions()->realTimeGC())

nodes.bodyText: I think TR_J9VMBase::initializeLocalObjectFlags() should be overridden  in TR_J9ServerVM to retrieve the initValue.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -4220,7 +4221,7 @@ TR_J9VMBase::initializeLocalObjectFlags(TR::Compilation * comp, TR::Node * alloc
    int32_t initValue = TR::Compiler->cls.romClassOf(ramClass)->instanceShape;
 #endif
 
-   if (!TR::Options::getCmdLineOptions()->realTimeGC())
+   if (!comp->getOptions()->realTimeGC())

nodes.bodyText:
You moved the return statement up. Is it possible that the code executed before this return needed to stay because it had important side effects?
getSnippetLabel()->setCodeLocation(buffer);
Will move it back to where it was.
Same here: You moved the return statement up. Is it possible that the code executed before this return needed to stay because it had important side effects?

nodes.bodyText:
I think this will result in many messages being sent.
The original code reads some value from the compilation thread (which could be any) to be used at runtime by any other application thread. This makes me think that all the threads have the same value which does not change in time. We need to verify that, but if that is the case then we can fetch that specific value once during the VMinit message.

I think this will result in many messages being sent.

So far the local sanity test shows that it doesn't look like many VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags  messages are sent for the following tests. I extracted out VM_getSystemClassFromClassName, VM_getClassFromSignature,
VM_getJ2IThunk, and VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags as comparison.
Running test jit_jitt_0 ...
#0208       3 VM_getSystemClassFromClassName
#0217    8679 VM_getClassFromSignature
#0307    1059 VM_getJ2IThunk
#0312       6 VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags

Running test jit_jitt_1 ...
#0208       3 VM_getSystemClassFromClassName
#0217    8697 VM_getClassFromSignature
#0307    1059 VM_getJ2IThunk
#0312       6 VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags

#0307    1059 VM_getJ2IThunk
#0312       6 VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags

#0307    1059 VM_getJ2IThunk
#0312       6 VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags

Running test jit_jitt_openj9_none_SCC_2 ...

Running test jit_jitt_openj9_none_SCC_3 ...
#0208       3 VM_getSystemClassFromClassName
#0217    8679 VM_getClassFromSignature
#0307    1059 VM_getJ2IThunk
#0312       6 VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags

The local sanity functional test shows that the number of VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags messages is relatively low between 1~16, except forStringPeepholeTest_0 which exchanges ~141 messages. Wondering if message VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags should be kept for now to keep it functionally correct on the realTimeGC path.

Without implementing the VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags message, JITServer sanity functional test might see server crash since this change enabled realTimeGC path that has not been exercised before.
Looked at the code, calling initializeLocalObjectFlags() should be independent of realTimeGC. I plan to remove the VM_initializeLocalObjectFlags  message. Running a bit more local test first.
